docs.lead_paragraph: When Kaori Sasaki was expecting her first child in 1994 at age 35, she repeatedly put off the customary visit to her local ward office to register her pregnancy, fearing that her maternity booklet would be branded with two boldface characters signifying advanced age. To her relief, she discovered that the practice had been quietly dropped.

headline.main: Royal Path: Late Births Lose Stigma In Japan

docs.abstract: Stigma once attached to having first child in one's 30's is fading in Japan, and this trend should get fresh impetus now that Crown Princess Masako has given birth to her first child just days before her 38th birthday; however, women who want to marry and have children after building careers for themselves still face myriad social obstacles; legislators have shelved bill that for first time would have allowed married women to keep their family names legally (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After struggling through a difficult pregnancy, Dina Matos, Governor-elect James E. McGreevey's wife, gave birth to a girl this morning. Their new daughter, born nearly a month earlier than the expected due date, was delivered at St. Peter's University Hospital in New Brunswick by Dr. William Scorz and Dr. Charletta Ayers, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey said.

headline.main: Gov.-Elect McGreevey and Wife Become Parents of a Baby Girl

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov-elect James McGreevy and his wife become parents of baby girl (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sophie, the Countess of Wessex, who is married to Queen Elizabeth's youngest son, Edward, was recovering in a London hospital after an emergency operation that followed the discovery of an ectopic pregnancy, a life-threatening condition where a baby develops in a fallopian tube rather than the womb. Doctors said the countess, 36, would need a six-week convalescence and that the episode did not preclude another pregnancy. ''There will be other chances,'' she said. Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Queen's Daughter-In-Law Recovering

keywords.value: ELIZABETH II, QUEEN OF GREAT BRITAIN

docs.lead_paragraph: People here worry about Dr. Irshad Shaikh, their Pakistani-born health commissioner. Not that he is a terrorist, even though federal agents raided his home last month, looking for anthrax. They worry about how much longer they will be able to hold on to him.

headline.main: Chester Journal; Raid and Investigation Unite City for Immigrant

docs.abstract: Chester, Pa, has united behind its Pakistani-born health commissioner, Dr Irshad Shaikh, since highly public Federal Bureau of Investigation raid on his home in anthrax probe three weeks ago; FBI has not charged him or others questioned after raid, or provided any explanation; Mayor Dominic Pileggi holds he is not terrorist; Shaikh's valued role in city noted; photos (M)
